subject: Re: The goals of CMM (Re: [junit] wanted Junit professionals urgently)
msgSnippet: ... I understand the timing issue in hiring, at least as an abstract concept. I just don t see why one would ever need 12 top-notch programmers in a two-week
messageBody:
Curt Sampson wrote:
> On Wed, 27 Aug 2003, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>
> > Curt Sampson wrote:
> >
> > > Unfortuantely, it can be a lot easier to hire five, or even twenty,
> > > not-so-talented programmers than one talented one.
> >
> > So it costs less to spend more? Great. Just when I think I begin to
> > understand business people....
>
> When I say "a lot easier," I mean that you simply may not be able to
> find enough talented programmers. Given two weeks, try to hire a dozen
> top-notch programmers, while paying salaries at the going rate. You
> may find it's much more difficult than you think. Certainly I've had
> difficulties this way when I've had to do hiring.

I understand the timing issue in hiring, at least as an abstract
concept. I just don't see why one would ever need 12 top-notch
programmers in a two-week period. If it's to start a project, that's a
tactical error: they will collide like crazy on such a small codebase,
so ramp up the team. If it's to save a project, that's another tactical
error: too many new faces at once will just make the project slower. If
you need a surgical team to come in and save a project, you need to hire
a team already in place and not try to turn 12 top-notch programmers
into the team you need.

The point is to hire 1 top-notch programmer instead of 3-5 warm bodies.
Cost less, more value.
